commentBody: Surely we could have put a fraction more effort into the clue for DEALS beyond a rhyme? I had to hunt for that first letter after mEALS didn't work, which is a rhyme that makes sense to me. The cross was no help either.

l had fun.  I thought it was clever.  Good debut.

Also, once you get the theme, it becomes quite easy.

I suspect our rugby people are going to be upset about 23D

Cute puzzle.
For those who conflated MGM’s LEO the Lion with LEO DiCaprio, you got your wish today.

A couple of Othello’s lovers?
I learned that an APOGEE can just be an apex, and is not necessarily the highest point of an *orbit*.
That was a romp, one second off my Tuesday best and faster than my Monday average…. Now I need something to entertain for the rest of the evening!  :-)
@heathiej!!! HAR!!!

"I saw my optometrist and cardiologist at the same time!"
"You can't! That's a pair o' docs!"

(Eye heart these puns.)

To paraFRAYS Gilbert and Sullivan: How quaint the ways of paraDOCKS, for me this puzzle really rocks.

For fans of covers that reinvent the original song, Patti Smith’s cover of SMELLS Like Teen Spirit is interesting.
I got it but I don't get it. DICEDICE?

Didn’t get the theme until I read the write up. Just went with the first word repeated in each entry and it worked.
I knew muffins was mess up and once I had a few filled in got bungle quickly. Started out with face instead of mano and hah instead of Har. But did 4 minutes better than my average. Nice puzzle

I could write several GRAPHS-GRAPHS on how I missed this theme!

After reading Sam explain it in the column I watched my ego SHOOT-SHOOT to the earth, and believe me, it's not going to SALE-SALE up to my previously self-contented state any time soon.

But MOUNT-MOUNT to anything else, even getting the theme, is that it was fun, clever and wicked. 

Oops, it's raining outside here in the burgh, and I forgot my SOL-SOL. There's probably a Biblical BULL-BULL about being caught out in the rain...
When I got the theme (from reading Wordplay, actually), I actually chuckled out loud. A very neat Tuesday puzzle!

The theme was more opaque to me than on many a Thursday. I stared at its entries and the "revealer" and understood nothing. I needed the column to grasp what was going on. *Of course* there was an abstract and phonetic element - my two nemeses rolled into one. Ouch.

The fill the would have completely defeated me two years ago - so much of it were words and names I have learned here over 24 months, including REBA, SSNS, OLA[F] (I can never remember if it's a v or an F), HAR, Alley OOP, and ESAU.

Strangely, I filled the grid quite fast for a Tuesday, without lookups, despite being clueless about the theme. Without previous NYT crossword puzzle experience I would have been completely stumped.

I can't say I personally enjoyed the experience. For crossword veterans with better IQs than mine this must have been quite nice, I suppose. Newcomers, especially from outside the US, probably have no chance of solving this.
Fun!   I liked the clever punny theme idea-made me laugh.   I got it by the 2nd theme answer -- I like this kind of pun/wordplay.   Nice debut!   More please!

Quite a clever puzzle and a very nice debut! Like some of the others, I got through this rather quickly, and really didn't pay much attention to the theme while solving. 

Thanks, Ingrid!

This was so smooth it was eerie.. you could even say normalnormal!

In a lellel universe I might have BUNGLEd it, but not this one. 

Nice debut!
Ruined a long Tuesday streak for me unfortunately. Never heard of GELID, and I had MEALS for the wheels rhyme. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Maybe it’s thanks to a good night’s sleep, but this went lightning-fast for me despite solving with down clues only. Having finished, however, I sat back to suss out the theme and found  it quite novel and interesting. Congrats to the constructor on a clever idea and execution.
Smooth as SILKSILK.  great start for a Monday night.
Very fun puzzle, loved the theme. Parafrays! 😁
Meh
This took me on a BOLICBOLIC ride. I wasn’t really sure what was going on until I did. Congratulations on your debut, Ingrid. Looking forward to your next one!

Easy peasy, with nothing sleazy or cheesy.

Congratulations, Ingrid, and welcome to the Times!(Repetition that makes sense is a lot harder than words that rhyme.)
Great theme! I can't believe that no one mentioned the Allan Sherman song "One Hippopotami" https://youtu.be/FVekfpXJGBc?si=hNqpFsncp1QA9BMJ
Didn’t care for the theme. But I’m someone who doesn’t really care about puns or gimmicks. I just like trivia and words.

Congratulations on your debut, Ingrid!  Didn’t quite get the theme until the clue for (DOCKSDOCKS), which made me think of an old rebus puzzle with a picture of two doctors (a “pair of docs”) which solved to “paradox.”  What fun!  Also, shout out to Ian on the Mini. Always love his minis. Anyone know if he has regular puzzles published anywhere?
Sam:  A fitting photo of Kauffman Stadium.

This was a very relaxing puzzle, so my SYMPATHETICSYMPATHETIC nervous system was able to put on a great performance as I solved. I loved the constructor's creative IDEA and had fun piecing together the themers. Thank you, Ms. Steffensen, and congratulations on a clever debut! Of course Foreigner's "Double Vision" would have been a perfect soundtrack for this puzzle ( https://youtu.be/dD-SpHH7qDA?si=OO68smhp_HhJOJDm) but what I really want to leave you with is a treasure from the Carol Burnett show, featuring The Jackson 5 and ABC: https://youtu.be/64n-t9Sw7F0?feature=shared Enjoy!:-)
Count me as one who appreciated the revealer. I knew to double the theme answers but needed the revealer to understand why :-)
Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Ms Steffensen! My review at Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/06/23/tuesday-june-24-2025/#ny
Outstanding!  Like so many others, I had no idea why the doubled words worked until explained.  I'm both embarrassed I didn't catch it and impressed by the puzzler's skills.  Thanks very much!
Paradoxically amusing.
This was so much fun. I actually had solved the entire puzzle before I figured what was going on. That took me maybe half a minute to figure out. Cute and clever. Wordplay.
Monday and Tuesday swapped?
Clever theme, kudos to the constructor. No trouble completing. But maybe I’m just slow tonight — I needed to read the explainer before understanding the theme.
Glad of the explanation of the theme. Very clever. Nice to see my name make a crossword appearance. That’s a first
The theme is great -- enjoyed figuring it out. A Tuesday puzzle shouldn't contain words that many or most readers won't have ever heard of -- "lades" and "gelid"?
33D:  Icy cold . . . "Gelid" (apparently pronounced "Jellied") . . . I did well on the SAT, but this word was new to me.  Am I the only one?  Or it perhaps a regional term?
Ian is the Scottish form of John, but in the English language. The Scottish (Gaelic) form is Iain. 😍

As a former Harvard postdoc, I had no trouble solving the puzzle but did not get the theme until I read this column. :-)

GELID was not a problem for me because I was familiar with "gélido", which I think is not as uncommon in Spanish as gelid is in English, and also has the benefit of sounding similar to "hielo", which is Spanish for ice, since they share the same Latin root.

grand debut indeed and great tongue twister! congrats hope there's more in the future great clues and fill mostly gloriously free of crossword detritus thats what we need thank you!

the less overused words the better is what I mean great work
Maybe it's just my accent but para and pair of sound nothing alike to me. Easy enough solve anyway
Awful theme.  As an attorney PARA is pronounced with a short A.  To make the theme work, you would need to pronounce it with a long A.  Easy solve but poor theme.  C'mon NYT, do better.

I love the wordplay, but I don't get why the constructor decided it worked better with plurals as the individual units.  A pair of dice should be "die die", a pair of frays should be "fray fray," and so forth, right? FRAYS FRAYS seems like a pair of "FRAYS"es (which I suppose could have been clued as PARAPHRASES, but wasn't).
Great theme, well done for a Tuesday!

Just about right. The words least known by me were the answers to 23D and 33D.

(Hi, Klara)

SS
BB
MM
UU
HH
TT

Really enjoyed this. Typical slow start for me, but finally tumbling to the theme was a HUGE turning point and that's always a nice touch for a tricky puzzle. 

Unusual puzzle find today, inspired by a search for part of the sequence of letters in our constructor's name. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
There are some real treasures in the comments today. I love this group and your plethora of knowledge! ❤️

Easy solve, thanks to the repetitive theme answers. But like many, I didn't get the theme until I read the column. And that's because I would never pronounce PARA and Pair o' the same way. So I remain underwhelmed.

Relieved to see I’m not the only one who needed Sam’s explanation of the theme, but appreciated the cleverness once it was pointed out. The doubled words clearly stood for something, but I would never have got there on my own.

Genuinely shocked to read @Sotto Voce’s explanation of New Hampshire State law re 21A. Call me an old fuddy duddy, but I can’t understand why any sentient being would rather choose an esoteric idea of ‘freedom’ over simple safety.  TBF this is a personal trigger for me. I lost my best friend when her Mum’s car was hit; with no seatbelts, both she and her sister, aged 12 and 14, were thrown out of the car.  This was 1972.  UK seatbelt law has been mandatory since the Eighties. 

Oof. My post has taken a dark turn. Still, a great debut. Well done.
Like so often recently I found this fairly difficult for it’s day,  but as usual don’t mind using help and enjoyed the solve.  I also enjoyed reading Ingrid's notes and look forward to more.
Didn't understand the theme until I read the column.  Pronouncing Paras as Pair o's doesn't come naturally to me so missed this one.
Para does not sound like pair of. Solve was fine for a Tuesday but what an awful theme.

What a fun one and a debut to boot!  I was zipping through and did not really try to grasp what was going on until I hit the reveal/hint at PARAS.  Had a good laugh there so thanks for that.  

However, my ear worm now, with a hat tip to Yip Harburg, is . . .

. . . "Brother, can you paradigm?"

Well done and thanks.

Lovely side road moment #1:
Realizing that the theme is even cleverer than simply the PARA angle, because homophones are involved – DOCKS represents “dox”, FRAYS represents “phrase”, etc.  Thus, a number of the alternative theme answers in the comments wouldn’t make it in the box today.  And props to Ingrid!

Lovely side road moment #2:
Finding alternative theme answers: SIGHTSSIGHTS, DIMESDIMES, LACKSLACKS, TROUPESTROUPES, BULLSBULLS, SALESSALES, SHOOTSSHOOTS  (on those last three – Hi, @John Ezra!).

Beauty in the box moments:
SCRUM, GELID, BUNGLE, SCOFF.

Remarkable moment:
I’m in the midst of writing lyrics to a song. One of the lines includes the word BUNGLE, and I’ve been unsure if it’s the best choice.  Then here it pops up in the grid – for the first time in 64 years in a Times puzzle! – filling me with the feeling that the universe is applauding my choice.

Add fun moments, and this turns out to be a momentous puzzle.  Thank you, Ingrid, congratulations on your debut, and I’m eager to see what you come up with next!

Whenever faced with a plural of an uncountable noun, I try to imagine a real world situation in which it might be used; which usually involves directions from a store manager to a stock-person. But plurals of plurals? Now all of the themers had the form plural+plural, but for some reason the *concept* of "dices" really amused me! For that, I imagined a toy or hobby store which sold phenaliaphenalia for RPGs: "Put the cubic dices on the top shelf, and the icosahedronal dices on the second." Am I the only one who had "gelid" in their use-vocabulary? I'm surprised that no one has linked this yet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MNeVjVu9O6w&list=RDMNeVjVu9O6w&start_radio=1
Clever and fun. Great start, Ingrid! Hope to see more puzzles from you.
Re: 26 A https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=x-SKCWXoryU

I would never have figured this out. Just not good at tricks like that. 
Para doesn't sound like 'pair of' to me although I can see that some might. 
Old faithfuls that I've learned  SSNS, ETC, SEMIS helped, and  I found the crossword quite straightforward.

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button. 

Strands #478
“Healthful helpers”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

I saw Eric's comment yesterday that a separate Strands column is starting up next week so since we only have a few more days left here I'll start today's thread. 

I agree that once Strands splits off into it's own REALM I'll be an unlikely commenter there.  As we've talked about before there is a very robust Strands thread over on the Bee column.  Wonder how they are reacting.
These "para" themed puzzles tend to be head scratchers for those of us for whom the vowels in "pair" and "para" sound very different.

All in all, I enjoyed this easy and very practical puzzle, although the second half of the double clues had me miffed. I stopped short of scoffing and maintained my usual elan.

Very, in music - I must not have paid attention to assai as a young musician-in-training, but I am familiar with MOLTO. Maybe it's because I never tackled Flight of the Bumblebee, or Hocus Pocus by Focus. The angry Speed Metal artists MOLTO ASSAI, of which I'm not a fan.

This has nothing to do with anything, but I watched Jaws last night. 

I hope Ingrid has vindicated the constructor community at the proper use of SCRUM, based on yesterday’s debacle.

Stubbing my toe almost never produces a yelp. It does, however, elicit interesting combinations of very descriptive expletives.

I don't have an explanation of why I like the word “laden” so much, but I always hear 
“…all ye that labour and are heavy laden…” Good memories.

If I ever run into our local meteorologist Parella Lewis at the next public gathering, I'll ask her to work GELID into her forecast. That'll have to be right before the restraining order gets issued. HAR

How Reba became the Queen of Country, I'll never know. She never really did it for me. Dolly, Loretta, Patsy, Tammy and not Beyoncé may beg to differ with her title.

Organic Chemistry inijoke; put DOC in position n of a benzene ring and then in A B or C and what do you have?

    n
   /\A
  |   |B
   \/
   C
A orthodox
C paradox
B metaphysician
(I THINK!)

I don't understand all the complaints here about how PARA and "pair of" don't sound the same to them. I don't pronounce them the same either, and I don't know any/many people who do, but they're close enough that I can certainly see the similarity and get the joke. I'm reminded of the Marx Brothers' famous routine "Why a Duck?" It's probably a small percentage of the population that pronounce viaduct and "why a duck?" the same, but, thankfully, most of us get the joke. Here's a short clip of the scene: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kHMrLpDHXc0 and for true fans, here's a longer version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=om45xUUVYGw

I liked this one, some of the answers felt a little obscure or like one step removed but I'm not mad about it. I am, however, learning that we don't all pronounce paralegal the same way. I'm gonna have to find a video of people pronouncing it because in my head even if I add an accent it still sounds like 'pair' in that accent... It's never too early for a rabbit hole...

Love this trick—when I got “para” and looked back at the double clues, I cracked up. Good job!

I also learned something today. I recently ended a 50 some year career in music, and I always thought of “Assai” as “enough”. Just like French “assez “, right?  “Molto ” was the fastest possible, “assai” a little slower. I never bothered to look it up. 

It took retirement and this puzzle to put things straight—maybe I’ll go back and look at all those Mozart and Beethoven finales!
(Of course for a violist, it’s kind of a moot point—we’re always playing as fast as we can!)
"Muff" is a common word used too describe an error in baseball.

I loved the theme today and thought it was very clever. My one and only complaint is the pairing of an extremely obscure adjective (GELID) with a “rhymes with” cross. I had “GELIM” for a long time because my mind went to “meals” on “wheels”. 

And lest anyone say “gelid” isn’t obscure, according to Google Books Ngram viewer, its usage peaked in 1834.

The theme completely escaped me, but I put this down to the fact that I've had several sleepless nights in a row. Congrats to the constructor on your debut!

For 64A, I can think of a few four-letter words I'd utter upon stubbing a toe, but YELP is not one of them.

Took years of piano, but I don’t recall assai. I do recall it from The Godfather Part II “bene assai” from your father loves you very much.

I (admittedly quite tired) didn’t see the pair theme, but it wasn’t needed to solve.

I also had meals as the rhyme. Gelid is… older than me ;)

Well, in my world, PARA- prefaces PARESIS or -PLEGIC...Or it could be HEMI-....gotta know the lingo!

Since I start most of my solves at the bottom of the puzzles, very early on I had PARAS and FRAYSFR..Aha!..  But because I didn't pay much attention to the entire 54D clue, I thought, "RE(FRAYS)!  How clever!"    

Delightful puzzle!  (I have only seen NARC; NARK looks strange!)

I was reminded of a funny quandry that developed when PhysicsDaughter was ready and eager to learn to drive...  but with the extra twist that her partial PARAlysis meant she would need to use hand controls.  I suggested she make an appt with the Rehab department at Cleveland Clinic, where we were Frequent Fliers; she came back frustrated:  "They won't give me an appointment for an assessment unless I have a driver's license!"
Well, that was nuts, but I could see she had done her best...so I stepped in....and after various mind-boggling phone calls, I eventually had the Head of Rehab Medicine on the horn.  I pointed out that kids who had survived disabling events were growing to maturity and expecting to do the same things as any other teens--like learning to drive.  But we needed guidance about vehicle, type of hand controls, etc.   New horizons for the folks at Rehab...

For some reason I was fully on the constructor’s wave length today, and caught on to the theme fairly quickly, finishing in a PB for Tuesday. Enjoyed the puzzle so much I was sorry to finish it so quickly. Congratulations on a fine debut.
I am too dumb for the bottom right of this puzzle :(
Fun puzzle, no lookups. Day 450 of my streak and a personal best for a Tuesday! Yay!

Congrats on the debut.

Solid, simple theme, just right for a Tuesday.

ASSAI was new to me, but the crosses handed it to me easily enough. 

I think four (short) GRAPHSGRAPHS will suffice today. Nice puzzle!

In her constructor's notes, Ms. Steffensen writes "I realized that it worked much better if the constituent parts were both plurals." Perhaps it's so obvious it doesn't warrant mentioning, but part of the elegance lies in the fact that the resulting words are either singular nouns (paradox, paradise) or verbs (paralyze, paraphrase).

***   ***

I don't get this "para" vs. "pair o' " kerfuffle, but then, I wasn't all that merry when Mary got married.

***   ***
ASSAI threw me off--I think of "Allegro assai" meaning "quite fast," as opposed to "Allegro molto" which means "very fast." Google Translate and the Harvard Dictionary of Music both tell me I'm wrong, but the HDoM admits that "assai" isn't as "very" as "very." But (Italian) musical terminology is full of these ambiguities--"Andante" would mean "(at a leisurely) walking (pace)," but then, what does "più andante" mean? Do you walk faster, or slower?

***   ***   

"Gelidus/-a/-um" is a good Latin adjective, but the Romans (or at least Catullus) also had "egelidus," which means "no longer frosty cold"--useful when you're writing "Now is the month of Maying"-type poems.

Fun and clever puzzle. A fairly quick challenge for a Tuesday. Took me 14m, which is probably close to typical for a Tuesday for me. 

I am too lazy to look for my stats.

Decent puzzle. However, feeling uneasy about London Insurance Giant. Lloyds is a bank and Lloyd's of London is an insurance market; I work in the industry and I do not think it would ever be described in that way. Like calling the NYSE a New York Based Finance Giant...

Not a complaint, but an illustration for speakers of AmE of why some might find the PARAS theme impenetrable...

In a fairly common Scottish accent, "para" rhymes with both "father" and "sparrow". In an accent spoken locally, "jaw" rhymes with "snow", rhymes with "ball".

You may or may not be able to figure out how those work, now I've given you a hint. But imagine solving a crossword based on those rhymes, without knowing there was a "sounds like" component.
Such a fun puzzle and theme. There were a few interesting vocab choices, but they were all getable on the crossings. An excellent debut!

My main takeaway is that I have absolutely no idea how many of you are pronouncing the word “paralegal.”  The theme works perfectly well for me. I genuinely can’t imagine another pronunciation and I’m very curious, if anyone wants to share a video clip.
My exclamation on completing this puzzle…or what you wear when jumping out of an airplane?

Whatever sweets salute the northern sky With vernal lives, that blossom but to die--- These, here disporting, own the kindred soil, Nor ask luxuriance from the planter's toil; While sea-born gales their GELID wings expand To winnow fragrance round the smiling land. Oliver Goldsmith: The Traveller https://allpoetry.com/The-Traveller;-or,-A-Prospect-of-Society

I had never heard of GELID before, and therefore nothing tipped me that I was wrong when I thought of MEALS on wheels rather than wheeling and DEALing. I feel bashful admitting that I needed the answer key on a Tuesday!

Late finds. First a puzzle and then that author's history. Anyway - a Thursday from July 24, 1997 by Randall J. Hartman. Six rebus squares in that one - three in row across the top and three in a row across the bottom - all of those placed synchronously. Anyway - those answers with the rebuses in parentheses, all of them clued straightforwardly: (TO)SCA / RO(BE)RT / TUT(OR) (NOT)ION / AC(TO)RS / ADO(BE) And then a 15 letter answer across the middle, just clued as "Shakespeare classic." HAMLETSOLILOQUY Here's the link to that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/24/1997&g=35&d=A But then.. I went and looked Hartman's author page and was quite amazed. 74 puzzles, all but one of them themed puzzles - Monday through Thursday. But beyond that: 229 debut answers in his puzzles - 168 of those never used in another puzzle. Some examples: BOSTONDIDNOTSOB CHEKHOVCHECKOFF CLOCKOFCHAIR EROSSAWIWASSORE WARSAWNUNWASRAW LEAKEYFAWCETT PARTONDIDNOTTRAP And just a whole bunch of other amazing ones. Here's the link to his author page: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Author/Randall_J._Hartman And his debut answer page: https://www.xwordinfo.com/WordsByCon?author=Randall+J.+Hartman I'm done. ....

Clever theme and nice having a gentle bit of trickery on a Tuesday. 

Doesn’t really work in my accent though 
(I don’t know enough phonetics or IPA to really explain what I mean but “pair” has sort of a longer version of the vowel in “pet” whereas “para-” is shorter and more like “pat”. Assuming you pronounce “pat” and “pet” like I do I guess 😂)
Before it was a global insurance giant, LLOYD'S was a coffee shop where merchants and ship captains would meet to do business. I think it's cool that they kept the name.

I had to smile at this theme. My British RP accent was established before moving to California many years ago. A couple of friends of mine, both doctors, went in together on a small boat and named it Paradox. They were so pleased with how clever the name was but I just didn’t get it! I had a similar dullness to the joke name Harry Balls. My Californian offspring pronounce Marry, Mary, Merry as homophones much to the surprise of their grandparents.

I first entered the actual word while going across (eg. Paradox) thinking the constructor had simply made up punny clues for the theme answers which all started with PARA. 

When I looked at the downs I saw this didn't work, and I had to laugh at myself when I realized what was going on. 

This was a clever Tuesday. You got me!  😄

I just want to point out that if you don't get the theme, then obviously you are pronouncing these words  incorrectly.

I'll see myself ooot now.

The arcane GELID crossed with a clue that doesn’t pair “wheels” with MEALS was too much for a Tuesday.

When I came across 55A I naturally assumed, without any other context provided, the clue referenced the massive, international “Meals on Wheels” charity program, rather than a seemingly random other word that happens to rhyme with wheels. I’m sure “deals on wheels” has been used in many advertisements for car sales, and was apparently the title of a British television program that ran for a few years in the late 90s, but I had absolutely no way to figure out this was the “rhyming partner” in question. When there is another, much more famous “partner” around, more context ought to be given in the clue.
Yeah for a Tuesday this was insanely hard? This felt more like a Thursday or Friday puzzle
Working through the theme before reading Sam's notes, I read FRAYSFRAYS as "rephrase" rather than "paraphrase".  Kinda works that way too.
The aha moment made me laugh out loud. Until I got to the revealer, I sure was scratching my head. This was brilliant.

Very Very clever. Too clever for my Tuesday morning brain, so thank you for the blog.

Meanwhile, if you’re suffering this heat wave with those of us in NY City, please stay cool and hydrated.

I'm even farther gone than I thought. Last night I was down to a few spaces in the SE, but figured I had something wrong. No English name would start "LL..." So I turned off the computer and got up to go to bed but I hadn't taken two steps when the obvious finally hit me. My GRAM, not DRAM, at 67A hadn't helped.

Some lookups. I needed the third letter of LE_A Dunham to know what _ANNYCAMS were. I thought maybe the musical "very" at 41D might end with I (I looked at a lot of music pages as a kid) but looking up ASSAI suggested it was just a store name. (I didn't finish RIOTER until LLOYDS this morning). And I was very slow to catch on to the significance of 54D, even after mentally filling in all those PARAs. But I'm still sort of able to do a Tuesday without Autocheck. How much longer?

Like buttah!!! 
Had my eyes dilated this morning, so I'm going to lie down and listen to an audiobook. 
Echoing many - stay cool and hydrated!
Was really thrown off by GELID. Never heard that before. Odd since I live in a frozen state 8 months of the year…

I enjoy watching DEESDEES on YouTube. They are often hit or miss, just like this puzzle. An intriguing gimmick, yet also poorly clued. The key to the puzzle is left up to sheer interpretation. I had to check the column to actually understand it after completing the puzzle. Fortunately, I am the greatest NYT Crossword solver of all time. I miss the good old days, where NYT Crosswords were even somewhat challenging.

Clever puzzle. It took me longer than it should have on a Tuesday to suss out the theme, since in my dialect the first vowel in "para-" is different from the one in "pair". Ms. Steffensen may have gone to UVA, but I take it she hails from somewhere west of the Hudson.

I absolutely LOVED this puzzle.  I was very frustrated at first.  I got the double word answers pretty quickly but how is DICEDICE heaven??  Then I got it...paradise...   
Like with Sue from Pittsburgh, the aha moment made me laugh out loud.  
Thank you!!  It helped me keep my mind off this heat for a half hour!
Really weak theme, some natick crosses, and straight up incorrect answers made this a pass for me. Where is editorial?

I got an inkling of the theme, recognizing "PARA" meant doubling (pairing) the words, but it wasn't until reading the column that I understood "pair of," which made everything much clearer.

Great debut and a fun Tuesday puzzle!
Please explain how Paras becomes pair o’s? I don’t get that…
After 17A, I had to pause to look up “One Hippopotami” by Allan Sherman. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=FVekfpXJGBc
This was a hard theme for a Tuesday! Congratulations on a great debut.

Cute puzzle, but you know you're not in Para-dice when it's 92 degrees at 9:30 in the morning! 
I got to where I needed to fill in 'Rhyming partner of wheels', to complete  'Very cold, and 'Very, in music'. All three had me stumped. Then DEALS popped into my head, and there ya go, done. I was shocked it was correct! I so had it in my head I needed a double 'e' word. Overthinking things, whew. 
Stay cool everyone, this heat is brutal. Let the outside chores and runs and all that go for now.
We need a cold front!
The parents of a friend in college were both doctors. I took inordinate delight in reminding him they were a pair a' docs.
Tricky for a Tuesday, but what a fantastic debut.  Congratulations, Ingrid!  Looking forward to more from you.
Love the Royals shout-out today…❤️

Solid for a Tuesday, I missed my best time by 15 seconds. I actually didn't get the theme until I read the comments here. I just discovered the doubled words and rolled with it, figuring it would reveal itself. It didn't, until here. Still, other than some forced clues, I liked it.

Congrats on your first puzzle! As a fellow Hoo, I also loved the puzzles in the Cavalier Daily and wrote for it. I never found others who had the puzzle obsession there in the 80s. I did hang out with the music nerds and helped run the Open Mike nights there.

Nice puzzle!

too many tv and pop music referencr: 1A, 5A, 14A, 24A, 43A, 69A, 6D. Not very interesting clues otherwise. The "pair" conceit is pretty lame. Not a satisfying puzzle.
Two words I've never heard of before on a Tuesday is, well...

Difficult for a Tuesday but what a fun reveal. I really had to think about it. I kept thinking 'two, double, and what the heck does this have to do with paras?!' Then, I extended the full term. Eureka, paralegals! And it all fell in place. It's those little aha moments that keep me coming back. Great job!
I solved without much difficulty, but didn't fully understand the theme until reading this column. Not really a complaint though; good debut and fine for a Tuesday.
TBH, I got the whole thing solved and I still didn't "get" the theme. Your column shed light on that for me. I'll do a DIDDLE DIDDLE for that.
I solved the puzzle but I didn't get the theme until I read about it. Happy to add it to my wins list but disappointed in its theme.

I am still getting a "grip" on NYT puzzle[s]. Mon. is usually an "ego" booster for me, that is when it is easier than Tues, but then, sometimes, it is the reverse!. At some point today, I resorted to looking things up. I do this when I am  my "wits" end & can also justify doing so because [1] I am a geography geographer [lol]; sometimes Latin. I do know French; Spanish: smattering of Italian & rusted Swedish. Still, I either stick with it, or must start all over again if I fade away. Obvious to me, that the writers, today, are fluent in the puzzle[s], but I find it quirky with the double words. I simply don't get it, except as a tease & I've learned nothing from this exercise. Where am I going to apply this double/double? The challenge for Ms. Steffensen [Danish, I presume] is also turning the puzzle on its head. Again, I am stumped as to what the point of these doubledouble words is supposed to mean.

I’m surprised so many people got TESTY over this puzzle. I thought it was relatively easy—perfect for a Tuesday—once I realized that paradise was both right and wrong.   The only thing to SCOFF at is GELID. I had no IDEA that is a word and it sounds so INANE I shall never USE it. ps I’m a lawyer and we say PARAS all the time.
Couldn’t believe I didn’t get the theme. But then I read Wordplay and wasn’t too disappointed in myself

Wow, super-clever theme - I'll be very surprised if this isn't the best puzzle of the week!

Very nice crossword overall as well - great job, magnificent debut, many thanks Ingrid!
Well I really enjoyed this puzzle and the theme helped me in the mid south. I needed the explanation from Sam to see what it all meant!

Assai doesn’t mean very, it means enough! Otherwise, great puzzle.
Clever clues, Ingrid! This was a fun puzzle. Congratulations on your debut!

I sussed out the theme, then 54D confirmed it.
Too clever by half for me, having PARA substitute for both 4-letter (DICE, LIES) and five-letter (DOCKS, FRAYS) words, albeit phonetically. I found the inconsistency off-putting.
Yes, the 'pair of' / 'couple of' substitution works better!

Very fun puzzle! I was reminded of the parody track by Allen Sherman, the Weird Al Yankovic of the '60s, "One Hippopotami," set to the tune of "What Kind of Fool Am I?" Best line: "And when Ben Casey meets Kildare, that's called a paradox."

Both ASSAI and GELID crossing a clue that could have a few different valid answers doesn’t feel like a Tuesday for me. In the end, after flyspecking and ultimately revealing the puzzle, turns out I just had a typo somewhere else in the puzzle. One of those days!

Yikes. No. The solve was easy enough but that theme was not it. 

Possibly an accent issue but PARA in Australia sounds absolutely nothing like pair o’. Do y’all really pronounce paralegal like “pair-oh-legal”????

Huge reach in my opinion. Some pretty lazy clueing. All in all disappointing Tuesday.

As for New Hampshire not requiring seat belts for adults over 18 in the front seats, I'm so surprised! I went down the rabbit hole and this is the explanation I found:

"New Hampshire does not have a seatbelt law for adults because the state prioritizes individual freedoms over government intervention in personal safety choices. The state's motto, "Live Free or Die," reflects this sentiment. While there are seatbelt laws for children, many residents believe a law for adults would be an infringement on personal liberty."

@sotto voce
Good lord. Is that true?? If so, I have no words…

@Helen Wright I grew up in NH and yes, it’s true. NH has a very strong libertarian streak and a strange governmental structure (2nd most representatives per capita in the world, I believe), so the politics can be really weird (and bad).

@Helen Wright

I’ve no doubt it’s true. I was working for the Texas Legislature when they tried to pass a law requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets, and the same arguments about “personal freedom” were trotted out in opposition.

@Allen 

I’m a retired attorney. The agency I worked for always had a few paralegals on staff. 

We never called them PARAS, but to me, the first A in paralegal sounds closer to a long A than a short one. 

Interestingly, I consulted two dictionaries while writing this comment. Neither one purports to have an opinion on how the prefix/combining form PARA- should be pronounced.

@Allen

@Allen

@Allen As an attorney, I pronounce the first syllable of “paralegal” as “pair.” So the theme worked perfectly for me. 

Cast your mind back to law school when we were taught to consider different points of view.
@Allen As an attorney, I thought this was an excellent theme.

@Eric Hougland
My wife is a NALS certified paralegal and worked as such for several years. Her attorneys never used the term PARAS. Perhaps the onslaught of texting and INSTA terminology made this mainstream?

@Allen the only way I could sympathize with the tone and severity of your comment is is “paralegals” didn’t sound like “pair o’legals” *at all*. I shouldn’t think of the latter when I heard the former unless so prompted.

While they don’t sound *exactly* alike —and happily for this crossword— they do sound close enough to one another to be evocative without prompting. If you don’t hear it, then you’re going out of your way to find fault with things.

@a.t. I meant to say (if the theme really didn’t work at all), I shouldn’t readily think of the former (paralegals) if I heard the latter (pair o’legals). Which obviously isn’t so; it really would take an aggressive lack of imagination for me to think this theme “unworkable.”

@Eric Hougland

@Nancy J.
Wow. I don’t get it. What’s so free about deliberately increasing your chances of death or serious injury? It seems frankly infantile.

@Helen Wright
Should smoking, drinking, skydiving, etc. be banned then?

@Hanson

Banning drinking was tried, but it didn't work.  So whether it should be banned is a moot question.

Smoking is proveably harmful and often fatal.  Banning it would probably be as fruitless as trying to ban alcohol.  But increased prices and intense social pressure have relegated smoking to the fringes of society.  That's a big plus in my mind.

The same could work with alcohol.  Making it impossible to afford and a social faux pas would reduce the number of fatalities caused by it.

The flaw in your logic is that while smoking and alcohol consumption are addictions, going without a helmet or not wearing a seat belt are not.  People will more easily comply to helmet and seat belt laws because they are not being driven in the opposite direction by a compulsion.

Skydiving?  Fine, as long as your CHUTECHUTE opens.

@Hanson
 As with @Steve L’s reply. Those are all voluntary actions that in general affect no one but the individual. It’s illegal to drink and drive. Simply wearing a belt doesn’t change individual actions, but may save your life.

@Hanson
Then why are books banned?

@Eric Hougland

Random deaths, like your sister’s, stick in the heart the longest I think.

@suejean 

You did have an advantage, though, by defaulting to "disc" rather than "disk," which is the preferred English spelling in many (but not all) circumstances.

This was one of those circumstances where, once again, I was forced to realize again how much consciousness consists of many different concurrent processes rather than a single linear progression of thoughts. 

I filled in DISk first. That gave me, when I came to it later, kASK. I was hurrying through that section, so  kASK seemed when I glanced at it gave me a sense of unease, but the part of me that was shouting about the misspelling just didn't make it to the head of the queue.

I've had times when, after I'd been struggling for the answer to a clue, I found what I'd been looking for, and simultaneously realized that at a slightly subconscious level part of me had been repeating the correct answer, over and over, like a digital loop.

@Michael

It depends on regional accents of English speakers in the U.S. For people in the midwestern US, the vowel sounds are pretty much identical. For many people in the northeastern part of the country, the vowels sound different.
"Pair of docs" and "Paradox" should be a familiar play on words for reasonably avid consumers of American English media regardless of how they may pronounce the words.
A few people seemed to have gotten it here: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/48dheo?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share
If there was no allowance on word pronunciation, then most puns would not exist.
@Michael    They sound alike to me, if I speak casually and leave off the F.

I am a lifelong New Yorker, and I don't have a quibble here.  They're close enough.

PRINE: I said, if you leave me with something - if I can make a noise, I said, I'll come out with a voice on the other end, you know? GROSS: So you got a new voice, and you feel different about it?

@The X-Phile

For me, they're a lo-o-o-ng way apart, and the joke was utterly impenetrable.
After reading the explanation in the blog, I've been repeating it in various accents, but still no DICE.

No great loss, since I'm not a fan of that sort of pun, and I solved without needing to know it, despite a thicket of unknowns in the upper half.

@Oikofuge

I'm not foolish enough to argue with a Scotsman about English pronunciation.

@The X-Phile

In spoken, conversational English in the North East of the USA, I would say they can be pronounced the same.

The O of "of" reduces to a schwa and the F of "of" drops off, just as many consonants do at the end of words or phrases.

So while a person may enunciate carefully and pronounce "lieslies" as "a pair of lies," in a conversation it could easily reduce to "a pair uh lies," which sounds just like "paralyze" to me.

It's kind of like "what are you eating?" reducing to "Whatcha eatin?"
@Renegator yeah, it’s not the schwa that trips us up it’s the PAR PAIR dissonance.

@Renegator
I see. But I would always pronounce the 'of' in 'a pair oF'
and say 
"WhaT aRe you eatiNG" pronouncing the letters that are in capitals. You can hear the 'r'.

Oikofuge,

So, how long would it take you effectively convince both of us that you have taught me what even a handful of those symbols are “supposed” to sound like, using only this forum? Discussing how speech sounds ultimately means we must hear each other, doesn’t it? Or very accurate description and interpretation of mouth and throat positions.  

At least with waving, I can probably count on you knowing what up and down means.
:)

So if I tell you that the Received Pronunciation of the vowel in "pair" is /ɛə/, while the first vowel in "para" is /ɑː/, then a slight knowledge of the notation tells you that you're dealing with a diphthong versus a long vowel. A look at the vowel chart tells you that the articulation is very different---mid front versus open back.
That immediately tells you why speakers of RP might have difficulty seeing the pun value in PARA.

Listening to the sounds being pronounced is really just the icing on the cake.

And I can much better understand the "Canadian raise", by knowing that it converts the common US vowel /aʊ/ in "out" to /ʌʊ/, whereas knowing that Americans think that this sounds like "oot" is not only no help, but actively misleading in my accent.

Oikofuge,

I’m happy that you are able to understand that. Clearly you know a lot about this subject in general and the IPA character set in specific. I’ve spent time now and then over the years trying to go a tiny bit more than shallow on phonetic symbols, but they refuse to stick. I defer to your authority on the ability to discuss accents in writing.

But practically speaking, in this world we tend toward something like “I say merry more like Gary than like Mary, except Great Aunt Maerey, but she’s from away.” And *that* as you say is a step further into the mire-y morass.

My English accent isn't very Polish at all. In fact, I cringe every time I hear a Slavic character speak English in movies. So stereotypical...

@Andrzej

See also Scottish characters ... I feel your pain.

Though there is a corollary, in which an actual Scottish actor performs with an unfamiliar regional Scottish accent, and is criticized by non-Scots for "doing a weird accent".
A classic example of this was David Tennant's portrayal of the serial killer Dennis Nilsen. Tennant did very well reproducing Nilsen's "Broch" accent (specific to the town of Fraserburgh in NE Scotland).
Broch is not well-known outside Scotland, and Tennant's performance attracted a lot of puzzled commentary.

@Oikofuge

My English tutor in the 90s was from Glasgow. She was very cross about some of the Scottish characters speaking with wrong accents in Braveheart - she said they could only be considered appropriate by non-Scots.

Also, being Slavic I can roll my Rs for days. I occasionally take advantage of it in English, channeling Peter Cushing as governor Tarkin in Star Wars 🤣

Still, I never roll my Rs in English the Slavic way, and I can say them the English way just fine. Also, my TH is as it should be.

If I played a Slavic character in a movie, nobody would find my accent believable 🤣
@Eric Hougland as a Brit, the first ‘a’ in ‘para’ is as short hard sound. As in Paddington. (Couldn’t think of anything more British that couldn’t be changed!)

For those who can use the IPA, the Received Pronunciations in BrE are approximately:

pair o'
/ˈpɛə(r)əʊ/
para
/ˈpɑːrə/

@Diana, agreed. The "pair o'" explanation didn't sit right with me for that very reason! I'm usually very careful to pronounce and enunciate correctly; after all, I am an example for the youth of Massachusetts as a third grade teacher! But I definitely fall into laziness/vernacular for things like "pair of" something. I know that past generations contracted "of" as "o' " but I (and most folks I know) tend to say "pair a": I forgot to pack a pair a socks! That matches with "para" better, in my mind.

@Eric Hougland, it's not a long a; it's known as an r-controlled vowel. The letter r alters the pronunciation of vowels such that they are neither short nor long. 

I teach phonics to third graders!

@Estelle Evans, it's neither short nor long, and vowels don't have "hard" versions; hard and soft are for consonants like c and g.

That a is r-controlled; the r alters the pronunciation so that it's neither short nor long. (I teach phonics to third graders!)

@Eric Hougland

ASSAI does mean enough--in Italian.  But it also appears to mean "very" in music, and in English.
@Eric Hougland and Taylor:  "assai" in musical tempo indications is Italian for "enough," not "very."  "Allegro assai" means fast enough, which is taken to mean not too fast.

@Eric Hougland that's just straight up wrong. While "allegro assai" might in fact be a rather brisk tempo, the instructions as written are "fast enough" (which  could in fact still be quite fast!) However that doesn't mean that "assai" means "very".
@Sam there's an accent difference, but not where you might think: I dont say pair o' with a long o like "oh". Pair o' dice? Pronounced like "pair a dice".
